author: Staff reports
title: Demolition of Tokyo’s Hotel Okura to continue despite public outcry
text:
September 1, 2015 Bottega Veneta photo of Hotel Okura 
Undeterred by the efforts of Bottega Veneta’s creative director Tomas Maier, the Hotel Okura in Tokyo will not be saved in its present form. 
The Hotel Okura Tokyo is a favorite of Mr. Maier, an architecture enthusiast, and when the designer discovered that the property was slated for demolition to make way for a newer hotel in its spot, he sprung into action in an attempt to preserve it as a cultural landmark by sharing memories via social media. Corporate responsibility efforts are common among luxury brands, but when a cause is close to a designer’s heart it likely resonates deeper with brand enthusiasts. 
Booking a room at Hotel Okura Last December it was announced that the modernist hotel was to be demolished this year, and Bottega Veneta commemorated the landmark’s importance to traditional architecture by asking consumers to share their photos of the building on Instagram. 
#MyMomentAtOkura launched with Mr. Maier sharing his own personal shots of the hotel, conveying his passion with brand fans. The preservation effort was also supported by architect Toshiko Mori, designer Marc Newson and artist Hiroshi Sugimoto ( see story ). 
In addition to a promoted post giving an overview of the #MyMomentAtOkura effort, Bottega Veneta’s most recent Facebook post from Aug. 31, serves as a tribute to the Hotel Okura and the brand’s goal of preserving its memory, even if the property itself could not be protected from modern development. 
Discover Ryuto Miyake’s illustrations of the Hotel Okura Tokyo, inspired by your moments and memories in support of… 
Posted by Bottega Veneta on Monday, August 31, 2015 
Although the hotel is considered a modernist masterpiece and a representation of 1960s Japan, the property will be leveled and replaced by a pair of glass towers designed by Yoshio Taniguchi. 
According to the BBC , Mr. Taniguchi is the son of the original architect behind Hotel Okura, built in 1962. The main building will be demolished in October, with the annex remaining open to make way for the new hotel’s 510 guestrooms. 
The new hotel will be 41 stories tall and will be open by 2019, in time for Tokyo to host the 2020 Olympic Games. 
Given Hotel Okura’s past, there has been significant controversy, with many opponents expressing the plans to demolish the landmark as “destruction of culture.” In addition to hosting delegates and celebrities from around the world, the hotel was also featured in the James Bond film “You Only Live Twice.” 
Luxury brands have put forth a number of efforts to preserve historical landmarks. 
For example, Italian fashion houses Prada and Versace helped to bring the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II in Milan to an online audience with the curation of a digital project. The InGalleria Web site, launched Dec. 7, lets consumers click through photos of the restoration process of the monument, as well as read up on its history and view a digital guestbook with visitors’ content. The site works as a digital museum for the building, as well as letting Prada and Versace delve into their Milanese heritages ( see story ).
